item.title: Delroy Lindo on ‘Sinners,’ the Oscars and the Power of Affirmation
item.description: In a career of standout performances and dispiriting lows, Lindo, 73, has held firm to his goal: “I want to be respected for my work.”
item.dc:creator: Clarissa Cruz and Marcus Maddox
item.media:credit: Marcus Maddox for The New York Times

item.title: Watch Renate Reinsve Struggle With Stage Fright in ‘Sentimental Value’
item.description: The director Joachim Trier narrates a theatrical sequence from his film, nominated for nine Academy Awards, including best picture.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: What Do They Eat at Awards Shows (and Why Do We Care)?
item.description: Interest has surged in what stars are served at shows like the Golden Globes. Does it matter what the rich eat, or do we just want to eat the rich?
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Three Great Frederick Wiseman Documentaries to Stream
item.description: This month offers a tribute to the prolific filmmaker who died last week at 96 and has a plausible claim to being the greatest documentarian who ever lived.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: BAFTAs Guest With Tourettes Shouts Racial Slur During Michael B. Jordan and Delroy Lindo’s Appearance
item.description: A racist slur, shouted involuntarily while Michael B. Jordan and Delroy Lindo were presenting an award, raised questions about how the show’s host and the BBC responded.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television

item.title: From Sundance Director to Head of Film Forum
item.description: Tabitha Jackson sees an opportunity to develop the next generation of cinephiles at the Greenwich Village art-house cinema.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: Under her leadership, Jackson said, “The most important thing is to make sure that Film Forum continues its mission.”

item.title: ‘The Bluff’ Review: She Has a Very Particular Set of Skills
item.description: Priyanka Chopra Jonas plays a notorious pirate who must protect her family at all costs in this Caribbean action movie.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘Days and Nights in the Forest’: Into the Woods With Satyajit Ray
item.description: In a new 4K restoration of this 1970 Indian classic, four upper-caste men travel for an adventure, with their entitlement taking a starring role.
item.dc:creator: J. Hoberman
item.category: Days and Nights in the Forest (Movie)
item.media:description: A still from Satyajit Ray’s 1970 film, “Days and Nights in the Forest.” From left, Subhendu Chatterjee, Samit Bhanja, Soumitra Chatterjee and Rabi Ghosh.

item.title: BBC and BAFTA Say They Are Investigating After Broadcast of Racist Slur
item.description: The awards organization and the broadcaster have ordered separate investigations into what led to airing the slur, which was shouted involuntarily during Sunday’s ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:description: The actors Michael B. Jordan and Delroy Lindo were onstage at the BAFTA Awards when a racist slur was involuntarily shouted by a man with Tourette’s syndrome.

item.title: The New York International Children’s Film Festival
item.description: Indigenous peoples, interspecies friendships, space travel and a history-making young paleontologist are on the bill for this annual event.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Graeber
item.category: New York International Childrens Film Festival

item.title: ‘Sentimental Value’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The director Joachim Trier narrates a sequence from his film.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: Russell Brand Pleads Not Guilty to Further Rape and Sexual Assault Charges
item.description: The YouTuber, actor and comedian had already pleaded not guilty to five other charges of sexual assault in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The actor and comedian Russell Brand arriving at court in London on Tuesday.

item.title: BAFTAs 2026: The Best and Worst Moments
item.description: Alan Cumming forced fishy British snacks onto movie stars. Paddington Bear presented an award. And a racist slur and swearing.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Eleanor Stanford
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:description: Jessie Buckley gave the night’s most emotional and twisty speech after winning the BAFTA for best actress.

item.title: ‘The Inquisitor’ Review: Barbara Jordan Is Speaking
item.description: This whirlwind biographical documentary puts Barbara Jordan, the esteemed congresswoman and professor who died in 1996, front and center as a voice of moral authority.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Rapold

item.title: BAFTAs Winners 2026: ‘One Battle After Another’ Wins Best Film, Besting ‘Sinners’
item.description: Paul Thomas Anderson’s comedy drama won six awards at the British equivalent of the Oscars. The best actor choice, however, was a surprise.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:description: Paul Thomas Anderson accepts the best director award for “One Battle After Another” during the EE BAFTA Film Awards at London’s Royal Festival Hall on Feb. 22.

item.title: Rose Byrne Can, and Does, Do It All
item.description: An Oscar nominee for a movie in which everything crashes down on her (literally), Byrne is shifting gears with the Broadway comedy “Fallen Angels.”
item.dc:creator: Leah Greenblatt and Sam Hellmann
item.category: If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)
item.media:credit: Sam Hellmann for The New York Times

item.title: Tom Noonan, Actor Renowned for Onscreen Menace, Dies at 74
item.description: He played memorable screen villains, notably a psychopath in “Manhunter,” but also wrote, directed and starred in well-received plays at a theater he founded in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Tom Noonan in 2015. “Anybody who saw him as an actor would know that he was the most shockingly present, immediate, in-the-moment actor,” said the actor and writer Wallace Shawn.

item.title: Political Drama ‘Yellow Letters’ Wins Top Prize at Berlin Film Festival
item.description: The film, from the director Ilker Catak, explores political repression in Turkey. Another movie set in the country, “Salvation,” took the runner-up prize.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Rogers
item.media:description: The director Ilker Catak won best film for “Yellow Letters” at the Berlin Film Festival on Saturday.

item.title: 2026 BAFTAs: How to Watch the Ceremony
item.description: Will “One Battle After Another,” “Hamnet” or “Sinners” triumph at Britain’s equivalent of the Oscars? U.S. viewers can watch this year’s show on E!
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television

item.title: ‘The Lost Boys’ on Broadway and Cynthia Erivo in ‘Dracula’: Why Vampires Won’t Die
item.description: With “The Lost Boys” on Broadway and Cynthia Erivo in “Dracula” in London, our horror expert looks at how bloodsuckers sank their teeth into pop culture.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: 5 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: At Berlin Film Festival, the Politics Are Onscreen, Too
item.description: Some directors and stars at the Berlin Film Festival rejected a political view of cinema. But the movies there suggest that politics is broader than just activism.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza
item.media:description: “Yellow Letters” is set in Turkey but filmed in Germany, suggesting that politics can weigh on artists’ freedom in Western democracies, too.

item.title: Five Free Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s lineup includes Spike Lee’s “Crooklyn” and other Black films that are just as rich, sharp and teeming with life.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Psycho Killer’ Review: Better the Devil You Don’t Know
item.description: A highway patrol officer travels the country to track down a hulking killing machine in this unsuccessful slasher.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include explosive trains, a hijacked plane and stolen submarines.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels

item.title: Watch an Ensemble Scene From ‘The Secret Agent’
item.description: Kleber Mendonça Filho narrates a sequence from his Oscar-nominated film, starring Wagner Moura.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: How Newly Found Footage Became ‘EPiC: Elvis Presley in Concert’
item.description: While working on a 2022 biopic of the King, Baz Luhrmann learned of unseen footage stored in a Kansas salt mine. That was the start of a winding journey.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey
item.category: Elvis: That's the Way It Is (Movie)

item.title: The NYC Theaters Where the Oscar Nominees Are Playing
item.description: If you want to catch them all, there are many places to see them in the five boroughs.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg and Danielle Dowling

item.title: ‘EPiC: Elvis Presley in Concert’ Review
item.description: Newly found footage makes for a fun and revealing concert movie from the director Baz Luhrmann.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘The Secret Agent’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The director Kleber Mendonça Filho narrates an ensemble sequence from his film, which is nominated for best picture.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: Berlin Film Festival Tried to Focus on Movies. Politics Stole the Spotlight.
item.description: Reporters’ attempts to draw stars into debates about Gaza and other highly charged topics have threatened to overshadow the movies at the Berlin Film Festival.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Rogers
item.media:description: Wim Wenders, the jury president at the Berlin International Film Festival, faced a pointed political question before the first movie had even screened.

item.title: ‘Midwinter Break’ Review: Aging Together, Growing Apart
item.description: Lesley Manville and Ciaran Hinds play an Irish married couple dealing with quiet resentments in this staid drama.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: Tom Hiddleston and Hayley Atwell to Star in ‘Much Ado About Nothing’ on Broadway
item.description: The Marvel alumni will star in Jamie Lloyd’s mischievous take on Shakespeare’s comedy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Tom Hiddleston and Hayley Atwell will star as Benedick and Beatrice, the reluctant lovers at the heart of Shakespeare’s comedy classic.

item.title: Lively v. Baldoni Tests What Crosses the Line on a ‘Steamy’ Movie Set
item.description: An affectionate slow dance. References to pornography. What rises to harassment on the set of a movie about a sexual relationship that turns violent?
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs

item.title: ‘The 2026 Oscar Nominated Short Films’ Review: Major Themes, Minor Lengths
item.description: Three critics briefly consider the short films nominated for the 98th Academy Awards.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis, Alissa Wilkinson and Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘How to Make a Killing’ Review: Glen Powell’s Lethal Case of Entitlement
item.description: The actor stars in this comedy with a high corpse count, but the movie’s lightness soon becomes forced.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘I Can Only Imagine 2’ Review: Dogged by Dark Memories
item.description: For its sequel, the Christian-themed drama about a hit single finds a new tune and an anchoring presence.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: ‘The Dreadful’ Review: A Knight in Frightening Armor
item.description: Sophie Turner and Kit Harrington reunite after “Game of Thrones” in this deeply silly horror fable that is haunted by an ominous knight.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: Seymour Hersh, the Investigative Journalist, Is the Subject of Netflix’s “Cover-Up”
item.description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative journalist who exposed a U.S. Army massacre in Vietnam is profiled in a new documentary directed by Laura Poitras and Mark Obenhaus.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television

item.title: “The Traitors” Host Alan Cumming Takes On the BAFTAs
item.description: The beloved Scottish actor and gamemaster of buzzy “The Traitors” takes center stage to host the BAFTAs.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Dulany
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: The award-winning Scottish actor Alan Cumming’s career has spanned film, theater, television and cabaret. On Sunday, Feb. 22, he will host the EE BAFTA Film Awards, known as the BAFTAs.

item.title: Billy Idol Had It All, and Then He ‘Lit It With Butane’
item.description: Last year, the British rocker with the iconic sneer played his biggest tour yet. At 70, he’s revealing how he survived the tough times in a new documentary.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Ariel Fisher for The New York Times
